reviewText:
Developed by Infinite Interactive and published by D3Publisher Of America Inc., Puzzle Quest: Galactrix is yet another puzzle roleplaying game in Infinites steadily growing stable of quality match 3 titles. The wonderful thing about this game, however, that sets it apart from the other Puzzle Quest titles is that this one does not take place in a fantasy setting. No dragons, no swords and no magic. Galactrix instead is set far into the future and deals with aliens, lasers and technology. You take on the role of a rogue M.R.I. pilot scouring the galaxy in your spaceship trying to uncover clues in an intergalactic mystery that will affect the fate of the entire universe.

I'm happy to report that the addictive match 3 gameplay is back but with an all new redesigned puzzle battlefield as well. Gone are the circular gems of the fantasy based Puzzle Quest titles. They have been replaced by the more futuristic looking hexagonally shaped tiles and since this game takes place in space gravity will be a factor in how the tiles fall. If the match takes place in orbit around a planet, the tiles will always fall downward but if you are fighting in open space the tiles will come from whatever direction you made your previous move so strategy will also be a factor in how you battle. The puzzle play is the same as always, you try to match 3 or more colored tiles with each color representing a different aspect of your spacecraft such as weapons, shields, engineering, computer, psi and intel.

Combat in this game takes place between spaceships. Your chosen vessel can be outfitted with a plethora of different equipment and armaments which are the equivalent of spells and bladed weapons in the fantasy based Puzzle Quest games. These items use gunnery, engineering, science and shield energy corresponding with the different colored tiles respectively. Make enough matches and build up the appropriate amounts of energy and you will be able to use that piece of equipment or weapon on your opponents ship. Take down your enemies shields and do enough damage to the hull and you will be victorious. Victories will earn you intel, which is the equivalent of experience points, which you can then use to upgrade the level of your character giving the player bonuses to different abilites. Another method of damaging your opponents vessel besides using your weapons is by matching the numbered tiles. These mine-like tiles have a different number 1-10 indicating the power of the damage output so matching higher numbers will be devastating to either you or your enemy. Throughout the course of the game, you will be able to salvage or buy a number of different ships each with it's own unique options and upgrade potentials. Some of the ships will blow your mind in both their design and specifications but they will not be easy to accquire. If you want a top of the line ship you'll have to save your credits, do a little haggling or get your hands on some unique schematics and just build your own. As I mentioned earlier, there is also a large abundance of equipment and weapons that you can accquire to further augment your warship such as laser turrets, shield generators, repair drones, etc.. For example shield inhibitors, which are my personal favorite, cause your opponents shields to stall out and not regenerate which leaves their hull completely open to attack. WWCPD...What Would Captian Picard Do? Depending on your playstyle you'll definitely find the right combination of technology to suit you if you buy it, loot it or craft it.

The story is quite compelling as it involves you solving a big mystery so you want to keep playing in order to see what pieces of the puzzle, no pun intended, you can put together and what questions you can answer. The graphics are top notch and this is definitely one of the more amazing looking match 3 games. Anyone who is a fan of science fiction will appreciate the beautiful handrawn art of the various alien species, unique worlds and especially the different makes and models of spaceships, weapon arrays and equipment showcased in this gorgeous game. The musical score is excellent filled with an abundance of surreal, jolly and haunting tracks which fit the titles futuristic theme perfectly. Sound effects are also quite superb. You'll love the combat sounds of the various weapons systems, the impact of the explosions and the sound of your system crashing when your opponent uses some kind of sabotage tech on your computer as well as a number of other terrific effects. Besides the combat puzzles there are also a variety of different puzzle types which involve hacking, mining, crafting, haggling and gathering rumors.

Puzzle Quest: Galactrix is just so much fun and highly addictive. One gripe I do have about this title concerns gameplay. The game is completely random yet sometimes it seems as though your A.I. opponent receives and matches multiple damage tiles so many more times than you do to the point of sheer ridiculousness. I can't tell you how many times I've lost a battle because so many moves that I would make would yield nothing for me yet set the A.I. up for devastating damage against me time after time to the point of me rage quitting....oh it's so frustrating! With that said, this is still one of the best match 3 games I've had the pleasure of playing and I will continue to enjoy this title for years to come. If you've ever found yourself watching an episode of Star Trek or a similiar science fiction show and dreaming of commanding a spaceship in an epic battle then this game does a great job of delivering that experience to you. Puzzle Quest: Galactrix is highly recommended for any match 3, sci-fi or strategy gamer.

I bought a brand new computer with all the trimmings to play the latest games and do video editing and and the first game I play? Puzzle Quest Galactrix. I have just finished it and it is partially true what they say about the crashes. I guess it will depend on what system you play will depend on how frequent it crashes but it only crashed a half dozen times for me in 32 hours of playing it.

Forget the crashes for a minute.
Story is pretty poor for the most part. I felt one of the strong points to the original Puzzle Quest was its story. This time, it has one twist about 1/8 of the way through and then you meet Beta Prime about half way through. The story does get better at the end but it's a long time to wait between the three major things to happen.                You could only upgrade your character to level 50 and it didn't feel like it ever really contributed to anything. It did to begin with but after level 20 or so, none of it really mattered. The only thing that mattered was the ship I control.                The game play is different from the rest of the series and this put off a lot of people. Those people are delicate flowers who hate change because it didn't take very long to understand how the hexagonal blocks work and once you understood it, the game was fun.                You could only upgrade your character to level 50 and it didn't feel like it ever really contributed to anything. It did to begin with but after level 20 or so, none of it really mattered. The only thing that mattered was the ship I control.                There are TONNES of moves. Unfortunately you don't really need to experiment much to find out which ones are the most effective. I tested a total of 10 moves and found which 4 worked for me. That's all I needed by the way - 4 moves. One move that destroys all blue tiles on the board, one move that puts the enemy in a time warp and skips a few turns, Bole Mines and one move that destroys all of a colour of your choice and lets you keep all of the outcome.                You have the choice of ships is pretty good. You have 8 or 9 and I collected the 3 that were practically handed to me during the story and while I could purchase or build others I didn't need any of them.                The different types of puzzle you have is quite good. You have the regular attacks against enemies puzzle, rumors puzzle, timegate puzzle and mine puzzle which were all subtly different and the variety was really good.                The map is really massive but it was never really used to its full potential. There were plenty of missions but there were whole solar systems where I would have a whole bunch of missions in and then at least one half of the map had 0 missions. Some solar systems were there purely to have one mission where I hacked the timegate and click on a planet to deliver something. Maybe fight one enemy at most. It really felt like the developers had huge ideas to go with this but run out of time/money.                Sound was really good but it felt like that was what was causing all the crashes. It did start to feel a little repetitive by the end, though. But the sense of grandeur was not missing in the soundtrack.                I really enjoyed the moving backgrounds. It wasn't overwhelming or pulled focus from the gameplay or anything but was just nice to look at. The graphics of each Solar System was very simple but I enjoyed it a lot and made it immersive.

reviewText:
Puzzle Quest: Galactrix was the much-anticipated follow-up to Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. CotW took your standard match-three fare and combined it brilliantly with an RPG. You crafted items, went on quests, leveled up, and battled, all by utilizing a fun puzzle game to get things done. Galactrix tried to reinvent the gameplay, which is commendable. But it did a really, really bad job. Which is not so commendable.

The first thing you'll notice upon starting, is that there are no classes to choose from. Okay, that's fine. I wasn't expecting this to play exactly the same. Then you notice that all of the characters are kind of ugly. Oh well, it's the gameplay I'm after. Let's roll!

The game starts off with a boring narrative by a boring character talking about how great he is or something. I admit, I didn't really pay a lot of attention, here - it was boring! Soon enough you're on a map, and now you start to worry. This is a little ugly, too, you think. Not hideous. But it is a lot less visually appealing than the original Puzzle Quest.

You do some missions, and the map begins to bug you further. Your ship follows your mouse, and sometimes when you go to a place, a character speaks. And then the menu for the location doesn't come up, because you have to go to the planet again after the brief scene to ACTUALLY go to the planet. You realize this sometime around the point when your ship is on the other side of the map, nuzzling your mouse like it's ready to settle down and start a family. What are you doing over here, you ask. Why are you not at the planet I sent you to? The ship stays silent.

So you hack a gate. Okay, that was kind of alright. Not something I'd want to do a whole lot of, that's for sure. An hour later, you will look back on this moment as the one where your life began to fall apart. If only you could go back and warn your past self. But it's too late, the damage is done. You're now spending most of your time hacking jump gates. And you despise it. It wasn't even all that much fun the first time, and now it feels like an actual job. You feel the hatred boil with every gate. Every screw-up. Every time the game gives you none of a color, and then asks you to match it for every other match. Every time you lose because you only had to match one more color, but the penultimate match caused a 10x cascade that dribbled on at the speed of sorrow. You briefly consider becoming a super villain to exact your delicious, glorious revenge.

Ah, but here we go! A battle! This is what we've been waiting for! And it's fun. And you fight. And you enjoy it! Boy, it seems like the computer's just having things handed to them, though, doesn't it? No matter, it's probably just a fluke. A coincideOh hello, future self. What brings you here?

STOP. YOU MUST STOP, PAST ME. YOU ARE SO YOUNG AND NAIVE AND INNOCENT. STOP NOW. THE COMPUTER CHEATS. HEED MY WARNING.

I wonder what that was about? Oh well. Hey, another battle! Oh no. Oh no, no, no. No, what have I done?

Puzzle Quest never cheated this much. At least not until the late game, when they needed to implement a difficulty curve to keep things interesting and keep you on your toes! How could the game cheat so bad, so

Oh, hang on. The game crashed. Guess I'll reboot it. And I'll just get back to that battle... Okay, here we go.

How could the game cheat so bad, so early on? It isn't fair, I tell you! No, maybe I'm just ill-equipped for battle. I should upgrade. But where?

And that's when you enter the final layer of Hell: lack of guidance. You can hack any gate and go wherever you please, right from almost the beginning. Side quests are available in nearby systems, and send you several systems outside of your hacked network. Soon you have half of the galaxy opened, and you don't know where to hang out. Where do I shop? Which places are best for me at my current level? Why can't I find any plans? Should I be mining things now, or waiting until I need materials? Should I ignore side quests until the story sends me to further parts of the galaxy? Is there an easier way to gain Psi points? What am I doing with my life? WHAT AM I DOING WITH MY LIFE? And you don't stop playing, because maybe. Maybe it gets better around the corner. It doesn't. But maybe. Please?

The gravity mechanic is pretty cool, though.

reviewText:
This is -the- worst, most broken, luck-based, cheating game I have ever played in this genre. Probably of any game I've played. Read on, because I've got legitimate reasons as to why. (Skip to the end for the short of it)

This game isn't hard in the sense of 'challenging'. The AI is so broken that every single move you make WILL result in a positive outcome for the enemy. You connect three red-energy? Mines (the attack tiles) will spawn in from the side in the perfect location for the enemy to use on their turn. You match three mines? The enemy will use a healing skill and an attack skill in one turn.

I am a big, big fan of the original Puzzle Quest and 100% it, but within the first half-hour of playing this game I knew it was nothing like the first. Instead of just a health bar (the hull), ships now also have shield that you must depleat before you can start attacking the hull, which are replenished by matching blue tiles alongside hull and shield healing skills, making every game a constant back-and-forth of damage and healing. As well as a damaging skill, all enemes seem to have a skill that destroys all blue titles (restore shields) and max all of their energies, allowing them to heal and attack as much as they like, based on the tiles on the board (they will always match mines when they can, of course).

The writing is cliche, the characters one-dimentional, the music repetative (I've not noticed more than one track), and the map is designed to take as much time as possible to traverse (each system requires you to hack the stargate between them, which is an aweful, timed minigame. Even when you can move freely through hacked gates, your ship pauses on each system on its path. Delivery side-quests force you to travel to opposite corners of the map just to click on a base and move on, and this is all within the first half-hour of the game).

What does the game have in its favour? Well, the hexagonal grid is certainly a change from the standard Bejewelled-drop, though the way drops are effected is confusing and hard to predict, what with the biased tile spawning. The character art is stunningly rendered and the ships are designed nicely, which contrasts against the ugly, copy-paste-hue in-game environments. The game seems to think it's Freelancer, having faction trust, mining/trading/bartering, and rumor gathering, but this is just a thin layer of unimpressive gloss over a shallow and broken tile-matching game that will not let you win.

I bought this originally on disk, but found it to be buggy.  I purchased the Steam edition on sale hoping that a patch would be released, but none appears to be forthcoming.

The rotating planet background behind many of the boards leaks memory like a sieve, and eventually crashes the game.  'Fixes' are available (basically deleting the planet image from the game's assets), but these only postpone the inevitable, as there are other areas where the game bugs out.

reviewText:
Like many others I picked this up in a sale at 90% off; and I must admit I still regret it.
I am a huge fan of the original Puzzle Quest and could play it all day but in comparison Puzzle Quest: Galactrix just feels lacklustre.

First of all unique character types are gone which could arguably be a good thing as it does mean that a long term player could customise their skill set (which are now ship parts to be purchased) and makes multi-player somewhat more balanced however the pay off is that the available characters portraits are incredibly generic and limited (I believe there is four) meaning you'll most likely spend the game looking at a character you dislike.

Continuing the focus on the games appearance the new puzzle board (if you can call it new) is nothing more than a simple alteration to a hex grid which is unpleasant to look at and difficult to survey quickly (Making the timed sections of the game even more frustrating) this is made worse by the spinning background behind the board which has actually causes a few of my friends who watched me play to suffer motion sickness once they noticed it.

Outside the battles in the solar systems that you spend most of the game exploring this genericness continues with nearly every planet, asteroid and space station using the same textures and scattered in a nonsensical patten across the system making it rather bland. The system does occasionally have other little ships flying around in a loop and their designs are somewhat okay though in the first section three other ships that are identical to your own make it difficult and confusing to understand what is going on.

The games music doesn't have much appeal, I rather liked the fantasy tunes of the original Puzzle Quest but this game it was just there having no impact on my mood or excitement (apart from the menu music which was rather good) I can't remember a single note even though I was playing moments ago.

Finally coming round to the gameplay and again the two words I've used to describe the experience so far continue to apply bland and lacklustre.
The Galactic map itself is admittedly big however manoeuvring around it is a complete chore as to change system you must first succeed in a timed “hacking” mini game which boils down to matching particular colours in order a certain number of times. There is no penalty for matching out of order but no bonuses either, the only way to replenish the time is to match clock tiles with three giving an additional 10 seconds and a match 4 giving a insulting 12 seconds. Don't expect these or even the colours you need to crop up with an frequency and you will often time out even on the easy challenges due to the general lag in the reaction to a tile match and cascading which just takes time in many cases, making it more difficult to hack instead of easier.
These can be bypassed later by spending PSI points but these require to be collected in battles and feels like a rather cheap way of addressing the issue.

With that finally done every system change then requires the game to load and return to the overview map followed by you then having to click the system you wish to travel to, this gets annoying quickly for short journeys. In addition you have to remember where anything is as there’s no information about any of the star systems for either game or fluff purposes which kills any fun in exploration, this makes the huge map feel like its just there to force you to play the stupid hacking game over and over.

Mining is also another mini game which is available and requires you to match a certain amount of tiles together of various goods to gain cargo to sell at space stations (only a few of them mind others won't let you and particular stations prefer different cargo) however the goods get strange pretty quickly with food, technology and contraband been amongst the things you dig up.  Seriously what are we mining on this asteroid? Did I just fire my mining laser into some orbiting spaceship?
In addition it is mostly based on luck and regardless if you succeed in mining the required materials or not the asteroid will be considered mined out and will not be available to try again until you re-enter the system.
The money you make from this is used to buy ship parts which give you access to abilities but the price on these are varied, you can also buy new ships which slightly change your stats and grant more equipment slots but these ships are extremely expensive. In comparison to the skills of the previous games many of the available parts feel rather weak or just useless.

The battles aren't much fun either, the board can consists of different colour gems to represent Gunnery, engineering and science which do nothing but power your abilities, Intel which is experience points, PSI which allows you to skip hacking (I've found no other use yet), shields and mines. With the introduction of shields as well of health and damaging tiles such as mines been extremely rare (except when the AI repeatedly cascades them) it makes the battles drag on, this is made even worse by the fact that the AI cheats regularly even more so than the original as stated in other reviews the computer will make a move and the gems added to the board conveniently creates chain after chain after chain often one hit KO a player at higher levels or fully repairing its shields.
Even when you win there’s very little satisfaction in it with the pitiful experience points or rewards.

Finally the story and side quests are bland with little variation and many of the crew doing nothing than symbolising you've unlocked a new feature in the story and devoid of personality. It could be somewhat forgiven if any of these were improved but the final nail in coffin is that the game suffers from crashes that the developers have acknowledged and decided to not patch.
That's right they have given up patching the game after its first patch!

If you want a puzzle quest game get the original Puzzle Quest, it was generic yes but it had solid mechanics and a AI that only cheated some of the time and was satisfying to crush not this lacklustre cash in on the Puzzle Quest series.

TL,DR: Bad game, don't buy it, if you want to solve some puzzles go browse the Net, there are a lot of puzzles on flash that are better than this one and are free.

I love puzzles. And this game features a few variants of a pretty good puzzle. Unfortunately this is the only good thing I can say about this game. Everything else in this game is bad. And you can find dozens of similar puzzle games for free on Teh Net (flash ones) only without spaceships, space exploration, RPG elements and mining.
Now, what I don't like in this game.
First of all, it's SLOW. Every ship has SPEED parameter. The big ship is obviously slower than small ship. Which means that I have no reason whatsoever to aquire an expensive ship at all. Because even your default ship (that has 8/10 speed) is slow. And the ship turns even slower. Its frustrating. Big ships are MUCH slower. And that leads to another problem. The upgrade system of aquiring a new ship and equipping an array of gadgets turns out pointless. Small and fast ships carry only a few gadgets. So why bother with ships and gadgets if by using them you will make your gameplay so painfully slow? And if this choice makes the game too hard later, well ♥♥♥♥ this game.
Next, leveling. You have 3 pools of colored gems that are used to power gadgets (red, green, yellow), purple pool for bypassing puzzles, grey pool of XP and finally blue pool that is your shield. Which is like your HP only it can be restored by matching blue gems. You get 5 skill points per level that you can use to boost one of 3 power colors or your shield. By doing this you raise the max capacity of said color, starting amount and speed of gaining it by matching gems. So obviously you dump all your skill points into shield until it stops to grow. Then you dump them into three others equally. That's all.
Next, XP gain. You gain it by matching grey gems. That's it. The rewards for quests, hacking and everything else does not make an impact. I was attacked by a pirate in quaris system that had a gadget that restored his shield completely. I fought him for 15 min. I gained more than 5000 XP. What. That was too easy.
Movement. You fly after your cursor. You finished your buisness on the planet (shopping, getting mission, finishing mission, reviewing your inventory) - you already flew away from the planet. If you need to do something else on the planet you need to turn around, which is SLOW. In case of missions of the main quest - next one is given to you on the same planet you finished previous. Which means that you will need to do this turn-around quite often to finish the game. It gets tedious very fast.
Grafics. I saw better grafics in browser flash games. Yes I'm going there. Only puzzles are relatively well done. The space is a static picture which rarely differs from sistem to system. And its ugly. I saw a LOT of much better wallpapers of starry space. The planets, asteroids, gates and stations stand out like a sore thumb. They simply do not belong. Again, ugly. Ships are ugly too. Though I may not be entirely fair in this. I constantly compared grafics of this game's space and spaceships to the ones in Space Rangers (first part). And those were made by a really good artist.
Saving. Every time you do ANYTHING that changes your stats the game saves. Which slows it even more. Why not make it save every time you leave a system and give us an option to save by ourselves?

Well that's enough. Vented my frustration and deleted the game. Good thing I bought it on 90% sale, bad thing I bought it at all.

reviewText:
It's Puzzle Quest... in spaaaaace. The game's big flaw is that to move to a different area, you will often have to complete a timed version of the puzzle where you race to make specific color matches in order. It's very annoying and frequent. Fortunately, it's easy to hack those timed puzzles out of the game.

The game also crashed frequently for me on Windows 7 64-bit, but running it on XP compatiblity mode and turning the music off seems to prevent the crashes.

So once you get rid of the mandatory timed puzzles and crashes, the game is fun, but it's just not as fun as the original Puzzle Quest. The hex grid feels too random, you have to spend too much time playing lame alternate versions of the battle (even aside from the timed ones), and the story is too grimdark (especially given that you can randomly blow up ships of any faction and they forgive you if you sell them some rocks).

As you can see from other reviews - this game is not for everyone.

I played the RPG version of this game (well the demo at least) and I picked this up at the discount price.  It plays more difficult and less intuitive than the RPG game, mostly because of the hex puzzles.  Yet I enjoy it at least as much, maybe more.  The strategy can be somewhat deep - and maybe that's why people are complaining:

THIS IS NOT A PURE PUZZLE GAME - like Bejewelled et al.  It's a strategy puzzle game where even the puzzles themselves involve strategy.  Don't want to take the risk of leaving yourself open for getting shot at?  You'll have to come up with a strategy of how to play (or not play) the board to do that.

I really like the puzzle portion itself - and add to that the remaining game logistics of character buildling - great game.  I think they hit the ball out of the park - but unfortunately, only for the limitted audience that can appreciate it.

reviewText: Props to Puzzle Quest for trying a new take on the format, but in the end it's not worth it. Some of the mini-games (for example, mining) are fun, and it's enjoyable to play it as a little space economy simulator, flying around systems to find the place that will pay the most for isotopes or technology or what have you. Unfortunately the combat, which is essential to advance the plot, is much worse than in either of the 2 'traditional' puzzle quest games. Both sides have shields which are recharged by matching blue hexes, and the hit points are higher so it becomes much more of a slog to do a significant amount of damage. Except, of course, that once you cascade 4 or 5 chains in a row you go 'nova' and then 'supernova', which doubles the value of matches, which means that lucking into a cascade like this can do 50 or 60 points of damage (about 4 hours into the game I was doing fights where both sides had around 90 hp and around 30 shields, and standard attacks were doing around 7 or 9). Combat then becomes a matter of trying to match shields and hold out long enough that you can luck in to crazy high damage cascades before the computer does. There are items that will let you do various other things in battle, but they're scattered around the systems which makes it a pain to try to find an upgraded laser or whatever. Just play puzzle quest 1 or 2 if you really need to scratch that match-3 itch.

reviewText:
I liked it but it wasn't outstanding. The 6-direction gravity in the playing field is good. The various versions in mini games are good. Its match 3, but the ability to push the board in six directions with the hex tiles makes it feel fresh.

I don't like the ship movement and avoiding constant patrols (with the mouse) in enemy systems. The overhead galaxy map has flashing planets that don't tell you whether they have a quest to complete there or a quest to pick up. It make traveling a pain. How easy would it be to put in hover text... or even NEW flashing over the corner of planet with more quests instead of places to complete the ones you have.

Everything in Galactrix feels so slow and unresponsive. Its just generally sluggish. I prefered Puzzle Quest Kingdoms for this reason. However I did like it, and I can still recommend it. I have enjoyed it.
